_header: The world so wide the air so remevable
Note: For the first stanza separately see 5534; for a disarranged text see 5788.
Title(s): On the Mutability of Man’s Nature due to the Seasons, the Elements, the Complexions, and the Planets
_description: John Lydgate, On the Mutability of Man’s Nature due to the Seasons, the Elements, the Complexions, and the Planets — eighteen eight-line stanzas (ababbcbc)

BodRawC86.First Lines:
The worlde so wyde þe ayre so remevabillThe cely man so litell
                    in stature…
BodRawC86.Last Lines:
…And or þu passe Remissioun fynallTowarde þat lyfe
                    where Ioy is aye lastynge

CULHh412.First Lines:
The world so wyde the ayer so remoueableThe cely man so lityll of
                    stature…
CULHh412.Last Lines:
…And I dar well say as to my felynghow shold a man be stedfast
                    in thys lyffyng
CULHh412.Note: Abbreviated version: seven stanzas only, and rhyme royal.

CamJes56.First Lines:
[T]He worlde so wide þe eyre so remevableÞe Cely man so
                    litill of stature…
CamJes56.Last Lines:
…And or thow passe remission fynallToward þat life where
                    ioy is ay lastyng

BLHar2251.First Lines:
The Sangwyne man of bloode hath hardynesMade to be lovyng and large
                    of expence…
BLHar2251.Last Lines:
…Herfor me thynkkyth after my semyngThat noman is stable here
                    in theyr lievyng
BLHar2251.Note: Stanzas 11-13 only (on the complexions), in rhyme royal.

BLHar2255.First Lines:
The world so wyd the hair so remevableThe celyman so litel of
                    Stature…
BLHar2255.Last Lines:
…And or thu passe remyssion finalToward that lyf wher ioye is
                    ay lastyng
BLHar2255.Note:
Full text in eight-line stanzas; includes attribution to Lydgate at
                    end.

         2. London: T. Richard, 1840: 193-8.
